description:
Wonderful experience. 

Wandered here after a weekend in San Francisco for my birthday weekend. We glanced at the menu and were instantly intrigued. They offered quite the Mediterranean-influenced brunch variety. 

I ordered the Lamb Burger and it being my birthday I had to order their bottomless mimosas for only $15, quite the bargain. Their champagne to orange juice ratio was perfect. The burger itself was something to try. The bun was crunchy and perfectly toasted where as the lamb patty was perfectly cooked and delicious. 

The service itself was an A+. Our server was exceedingly friendly and polite. She even overheard that it was my birthday and brought out a birthday dessert at no charge. I was not only surprised but overly grateful at this kind gesture. 

The service here and the food is something to try. Loved the food and the overall experience. I highly recommend to anyone.
author: Rick S.

description:
The meal was bad, The service was really bad and unfriendly.
Most of the drinks on the menu were not available and the worst part was that I gave them 15 percent tip but they charged my card 25 percent. Very bad experience.
Will Never Try It Again!
author: Iman K.

description:
My fave place for fresh, clean Mediterranean food! 
My fave dishes: Petaluma Chicken, beef kofta, hummus with Pita (warm and freshly baked) with a glass of Red wine 

The waitstaff is very friendly, its a nice little gem in a cool part of the city for dinner after shopping in Union Square
author: Courtney G.

description: First I want to say the bartenders are always very nice and helpful especially when it comes to choosing wine. I LOVE their tatziki. They make it the right way. It's not watery at all- it's extremely creamy and flavorful. The lentil tomato soup is delicious!  I had a quick dinner here a few nights ago and as usual left pleased with my meal. I definitely recommend this spot for anyone that enjoys Mediterranean food. Dunya is consistently good.
author: Danielle S.

description: Came here for my 21st. The food and bottomless mimosas are SO good. I got eggs benedict. Bottomless mimosas that are only $15?? Count me IN. Would definitely recommend this place for brunch - it's definitely a hidden gem.
author: Sonali G.

description: Wow, Adana Kebab is so good!! Perfectly cooked, I loved the onions, very well marinated and yummy. I would definitely recommend this place to a family member and friends.
author: Gabrielle G.

description:
Before dinner, I was coming with my friend. The place is located in hot spot a little distance to downtown area. And close to NobHill, so there're so many people who stay in this district come & enjoy drinking. That will be one of my favorite mediterranean places.

I ordered Pale Ale, they have a variety of beers. You can enjoy at cheap, and spend time with your precious friends, maybe.
author: Shun Y.

description:
My experience here was for a late dinner affair with a party of 4. The restaurant was dark and the chatter of the neighboring tables persisted throughout the night. It was fine for a lively group of family and friends, but I could imagine it being a bit rowdy for a date.

We shared the Meze Platter, which consisted of 3 or 4 small falafels (if I had it my way there would be more of these - fairly firm on the outside although could be crispier), hummus, a diced eggplant concoction (smoky, savory, and addictive), creamy tzatziki, dolmas (pickled rice, currants, and pine nuts wrapped in grape leaves), and pita bread. This appetizer was filling and the portions were generous.

We also had the Calamari Palermo, which was a tomato sauce based dish with sauteed artichoke and garlic. The calamari was fresh and the artichoke added something a little unexpected to the dish.

The entree list was fine, but since I don't eat lamb, that limited the options since the beef and lamb dishes could not be made without lamb. I opted for the Vegan Pyramid, a vegetarian dish, to avoid what might be dry chicken breast. The entree was a stack of eggplant, portobello mushroom (just 1 of these), and some other vegetables in tomato sauce, which lacked a bit of creativity in terms of flavor.

The wine selection was decent and we had a nice, robust red wine. Service was fine.
author: Cici T.

description:
Can I just say I'm so glad I went here last night for dinner. This place is more wine than cocktail that's for sure. We started our Friday night with two Stella and truffle fries. 

I told my friend can we go somewhere light weight healthy? And so we ended up at Dunya. We both ended up ordered the angus beef burger. Ahahaha, so much for a healthy meal. 

The truffle fries were thick and thin, like they sliced it themselves. It was soft with potato skin still on the fries. Like fries from in n out but a little thicker. The burger came out with fries and a salad. The burger was cooked medium rare (although our first bite showed that the burger looked more medium/medium well than medium rare) with a tomato, onion, one lettuce, and topped with buffalo cheese. There was a pink dressing on the burger as well. 

Can I just say that this was the best burger I've ever eaten. I think it was the cheese. I ate half of it and brought the other half home and my mom confirmed that it was one of the best burgers she's ever had. She said it probably would have been better if it were eaten fresh. I told her it was great. I probably should have also gotten something traditional, but I'm not a fan of lamb. 

Our server was super friendly and very attentive. I'd love to come back and try something more traditional with a side of burger ahahah. Obsessed
author: Ameenah M.

description:
Came to Dunya with friends on a friday night, it was packed but we had reservation and seated at a nice table. We ordered a bottle of Turkish wine(Şayeste, 2011), it wasn't on the menu but ask for Turkish wine to your server, believe me you won't regret it. 

We ordered Beyti, Adana and Mix Grill, both presentation and taste was excellent. Portions were generous and the food was one of the most authentic Turkish food I had in a long while. My favorite was Beyti! Don't forget to order Kunefe as dessert after your meal, it was one of the best I had.

The owner(and the chef) Coşkun took care of us whole night and made sure everything was perfect. He is a great chef and a people person. Overall it was a great night and well above my expectations! 

I will definitely come here again.
author: Berk G.

description:
I am at Dunya at least once a week! Always good service.
I like the variety of wine, I would definitely recommend Petaluma chicken or salmon Provençal, and kunefe with ice cream for desert
author: Marichka K.

description: Dunya Bistro is the best Mediterranean restaurant I've ever been to.  My favorite food there is the mixed grill which includes beef, lamb, and chicken.  The taste is pretty delicious.  The waitstaff is very friendly, helpful and talkative. It is located on Polk street.  If you really want to enjoy your food, you should drink Turkish wine with your meal.
author: St Giles I.

description: Hands down it is my favorite wine spot in the city! They serve awesome delicious food. Portions are huge! Great atmosphere & excellent service! When you are in definitely ask for Haniel. He is the BEST! He is always super friendly with a great vibe. I highly recommend this place. This place is a must!
author: Kat Z.

description:
Service was definitely better than the food. Came for happy hour for a quick drink and bites.  Great selection of food, unfortunately sub par.   We had the eggplant purée (bland, needs more flavor), dolsa stuffed with grape leaves (bland, needs more flavor) and the lamb meatballs (better than the rest, actually I preferred the sauce over the actual meatball).

Food 2
Service 4
Overall 3
author: Patrick C.

description: Had the chicken kabab for entree and falafel for appetizer. Both were good and the ambience is good too.
author: Ash M.

description:
We happened to come by during happy hour. It was a tight fit, but we managed even with the stroller. We ordered a number of the appetizers:  
- lamb meatballs- 6.5/10. I thought it strange to pair it with a red sauce; seems more Italian.)
- Falafel - 6.5/10. fried a little harder, but still good. 
- walnut paste- 7/10. Different than the Georgian version. Tasty and popular at the table. 
- borek- 4/10. I've only had the more bread like version. This was like an egg roll stuffed with cheese. 

With that much food already, we chose only 2 entrees:  
- mixed grilled meats- 7/10. There was lamb, beef, and chicken. Chicken was a bit dry. Lamb was good. Beef was the best. 
- stuffed eggplant- 5/10. not so much stuffed as topped.  Not a memorable dish. 

Overall, the food was good and the price was as expected for the area.  No complaints on service. Wouldn't make a special trip out here for this.
author: Lan N.

description:
Fun place where you can get drunk off good wine for a very good price. The reds are about $40, which is not bad at all. There are Mediterranean wines, Spanish wines, and Californian wines. I chose the one with the weirdest spelling, and even my waiter couldn't pronounce it. 

Also ordered the pita with eggplant puree, and although I'm not a huge eggplant fan, I loved how fresh the puree was and how it was seasoned. Coupled with the warm, pillowy pita, it was the perfect complement to the wine. 

While I had a good time, I didn't have as good a time as the ladies next to us, who spilled champagne all over the phone of the poor guy eating with them.
author: Sophie W.

description:
Really good ambience and great food! We were pleasantly surprised
We ordered Lentil Soup, Ezme and Musakka - loved all with Ezme being the fav
We would come again to try more apps!!
author: Vidushi S.

description: Good food, good kebabs! Came back after 3 years, food is still excellent! But was shocked to see the price hike. I guess it's to adjust to SF average:( I am a little confused about the atmosphere, the music is sonewhat club like at night... But I come here for food.
author: Lauren P.

description:
Went here for brunch. Had the Mediterranean Ranchero aka medit breakfast pizza. It was really good and had all the right flavor combos.

The potatoes on the side were delish as well. No espressos unfortunately.
author: Ana G.

description: I did not give tip for not satisfied with the service. however, employees charge $ 15 from me. this is theft. then when I go to the restaurant, the employee gave me the answer, this place is san francisco and you have to give me the tip. he said if you don't, i won't give service you. very bad experience. If you go, I suggest you check your account.
author: Mete O.

description:
This is a great Turkish run restaurant on Polk St. with a full bar and a good menu selection of Mediterranean dishes.

It is one of the few places that I know of that has Adana Kebab, my favorite when visiting Turkey, along with tender, and I mean tender, chicken Kebabs.  Get the mixed grill platter to enjoy three kebabs, Adana, Chicken and Lamb with salad and rice.  Wonderful and will easily feed two to three people.  

The wait staff are very friendly and the service is good.  A great find on Polk St.
author: David T.

description: Got tea here with 2 friends. I had green tea. It was a nice place to sit and chat...and might I add it was late at night on a Sunday!
author: Denise C.

description:
Really enjoyed the food here, service was meh. 

We started with the calamari palermo, which I had high hopes for, but it definitely lacked flavor. 
My friend ordered the adana kebab, and I ordered the salmon provencal, which we both really enjoyed. (both pictured) 

They serve really big portions, just to note. Overall, definitely enjoyed! Will be back again! Would love to try out more of the menu!
author: Kim B.

description: Seriously amazing food and ambience. Everything we ordered- from appetisers to entrees to the wine- was awesome. Very cosy atmosphere. Highly recommend this place.
author: Vyoma K.

description:
Good atmosphere with nice music and good service from the servers. The food was excellent. I tried chicken kebab, lamb burger, lamb skewers, lentil soup and calamari.

I highly recommend.
author: Kemal K.

description: Wine, wine, and wine! Sip and enjoy! With decent food to pair, their menu really is about realizing what liquid you wish to imbibe. The service is good, not a busy place but there are limited seats. Great for a daytime meet-up for lunch or an early dinner meal. Be sure to ask what the specials are!
author: Lidia D.

description: Pretty good food but I don't think of it as particularly memorable. Been here a few times and the most I remember is that it is a bit pricey for what you're getting (common for the city) - but I've never been here where anyone felt dissatisfied or unhappy with their food.
author: Lily R.

description:
Got a chance to visit this place for the first time last Saturday. 
We ordered Mess e platter, Lamb Meatballs, Calamari, Shrimp and Falafel.  
The Food and the Service were beyond Excellence.  
I would recommend this place to anybody who wants Best Experience when it comes to Mediterranean Food.  
It was so good that I had to meet the owner of this place and congratulate him, Down to the Earth gentleman he is.
author: Sunny C.

description: I definitely recommend this place for brunch!! It's a small place, but the service is amazing!!! They're CONSTANTLY filling up your glasses which is always a necessity when doing bottomless mimosas. The eggs Benedict was delicious too! The hollandaise sauce was yummy too. I literally spent like over 5 hours debating between 3 brunch places and ended up choosing Dunya and I'm SO glad I did!! They take reservations, food was amazing, and the service was exceptional!
author: Kim P.

description: This is very nice and cozy place. Mediterranean food is delicious and portions are big. I also like playlist there and they have wonderful bartender Sam. He knows all sorts of wine and makes delicious cocktails. Highly recommend this place.
author: Svetlana N.

description: Really good food I tried the Adana lam kebab it was fantastic and the mixed appetizers was fabulous PLUS such a friendly stuff, thank you Gizem (çok sağul)!
author: Mustafa A.

description: This's a great place to have diner and chat with your friends on late Friday night. I would recommend this place to anybody who wants Mediterranean food. The bartender Sam was great.
author: Sasha A.

description: Meza plate was yummy; Pasha wrap was good.  Veggie Panini was burnt and not at all like a panini.  But the bottle of wine helped blunt the disappointment.
author: Irenee B.

description: I've walked by this place twice a day walking to work for the last two years and never managed to give it a shot. What the hell was I thinking? This place is a treasure trove of delicious wine selections, incredible food and awesome staff. We've gone three times in three weeks since taking the plunge and plan to gain regular status ASAP. This is a locals gem with happy hour specials, brunch menus and tasty treats.
author: Nic F.

description: My 2 friends and I went on 03/17.  It was busy that the only seats were at the bar.  We all got the Bottomless Mimosas and the bartender was great. He made sure to keep in eye on our glasses and filled them up quickly every time.  I got the Pastrami Sandwich (Melted provolone, fresh tomatoes, green onions and lettuce).  It was so good!  I would get it again.  The only negative thing I can say about the experience or food was that the fries could have been a lot more crispy.
author: Jason S.

description:
Came here for brunch thinking it would be interesting. Ordered the protein bowl, didn't come with beef but lamb and very few veges, not worth $16.

Also, terrible service except when you ask for a check, then they are super quick in making sure you pay quickly. 

Overall, not worth visiting for brunch.
author: Marlyn F.

description: I'd give this place 3.6 stars.  I went during happy hour, so the prices were reasonable.  The bartender Sam was great.  The food was OK. The restaurant is visually nice.
author: Sharon M.

description: Service probably deserves 3 star but the food is pretty good and they have good happy hour specials. The Tzatziki is really good but the fries are inconsistent. Sometimes they taste great and others the texture is dry and cardboard inside. They are fresh handcut fries though- no frozen bs here. I want to go back and try more things because I think the food tastes fresh and flavorful.
author: Piper W.

description:
This place is one of my favorite Mediterranean places in the city! 
The Hummus is amazing, I usually have the chicken skewers which are so yummy, last night we tried Beyti which was also very delicious! 
Great wine prices as well.
author: Lina L.

description:
Came here for dinner. Good atmosphere, feels kind of alike a wine cellar. I'm a stickler for middle eastern food so take my review with a grain of salt but I would give the food 3 stars and bumped the overall review to 4 for service and ambiance. 

The food is simple and self explanatory, nothing too special or extraordinary. It was well cooked, but small portions for the price. Typical to that area. The rice could have been prepared with more flavor for sure. 

Overall, it's a great spot for a date night or a casual dinner with a glass of wine but if you're looking for quality middle eastern kabobs and rice, there are better places I would try Lavash on 9th. Still a great spot though, I would come back.
author: Samyutha R.

description:
Heather H took a break from this platform. She wanted to stay positive on all fronts in 2017 but broke-down with this terrible restaurant. 
The service was... well - plan on spending 3 hours from the time you get in to the time you leave to get service.  
Well, no surprise--the food came out cold (why did I do this to myself... the mantra in my head played on and on) I could have left. Everyone deserves a chance. Well, not Dunya. You will thank me...
author: Jill F.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in the city. I've been coming here for many years and it never disappoints! Beautiful interior, big selection of wine, friendly and helpful stuff and of course absolutely delicious food !!! They also have IPA and Pilsner on tap if you prefer beer over wine. There are food options for meat lovers as well as vegetarian folks. So no one will leave hungry :) If you are in the neighborhood, or just looking for a high quality Mediterranean food, stop by. This is the place you don't want to miss.
author: Anastasia S.

description:
I ate here 3 days ago in a very large group and the staff coped fantastically well
The lamb kebab and salmon were the best I've ever had and the menu is reasonably priced
Great selection of dishes and drinks and very friendly staff
Lovely restaurant 
I look forward to my next visit
author: Kurtulus K.

description: It has a very unique feel. Our food came in big portions with great sides. Our plates looked beautiful and tasted as good as they looked. Highly recommend this place for anyone who enjoys Mediterranean food. The staff was also very friendly.
author: Dilvin I.

description:
Turkish food is always a good look, but I felt that Dunya didn't live up to the quality of food I've had at other Turkish restaurants in the immediate area. There are a couple Turkish spots in the Tenderloin that I would rather go to.

Here's why: 

1. Portions: Dunya tends to skimp out on the amount of meat in the kebab dishes and the amount of rice that comes with it. 

2. Price: the prices on yelp are outdated and have been jacked up recently. For $16 I expected to get a lot more meat :/

That aside, the Aldana Kebab was spectacular. We ended up ordering a second one for our group. Definitely recommend getting that--but again, wish there was more of the kebab on that plate :(
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
Came here for dinner with some friends on new years eve. Made a reservation on the phone and was quickly seated.

With dimmed lights and classic songs playing, the atmosphere is nice and relaxing.  

The food is pretty good. I ordered the adana kabob which was nicely seasoned and came right a side of veggies and rice.  My friends ordered an eggplant dish and the salmon.  The salmon seemed to be a bit under seasoned which was kind of disappointing, but it was still cooked alright.

We also shared a bottle of wine, which was an average bottle of moscato.

Overall experience was positive. The price is a bit high, but this is San francisco, where everything is more expensive than anywhere else in the US.
author: Jacky C.

description: Came here for brunch because their bottomless was reasonably priced. The atmosphere is good, the service was a little slow and the food was good but nothing to rave about. However, I'll definitely be back to try one of their platters with wine at night.
author: Lauren A.

description: Cute place with a great vibe and ambiance but the food was just ok... we ordered the chicken kebab, stuffed eggplant and beyti kebabs. The Beyti kebabs were the best of the meal but I have definitely had better. They did seem to have a good happy hour so I will be back to check it out.
author: Rachel N.

description:
Ive never been to a Mediterranean restaurant I didnt like.... until now. We wandered in for lunch after reading the menu posted outside. The place is small and cute with so much potential. After being greeted, I could immediately tell the server was overwhelmed. Her demeanor was short, but I giver her a little pass since she was the hostess, server, bartender and busboy for the entire place.  She literally had no help and it was lunchtime!

We ordered salad, lamb meatballs, and the mezze platter. The meatballs were tough and everything on the mezze platter lacked flavor, except for the tzatziki. My sister said the salad wasnt bad.

Lastly, we ordered two glasses of wine and one was noticably underpoured. I was disappointed all around with this establishment.
author: Brandi H.

description: Went to SF for my normal hair cut and my bff and me walked and found this place. I'm so happy we found this place. We started with a glass of the sparkling rosè and the prawn appetizer with melted feta cheese. It's so good you'll want extra pita to get every drop of the sauce. I had the roasted half chicken and my friend had the angus burger with truffles fries. Let's just say our plates are empty. Then we had the salted Carmel gelato & mango panna cotta. Delicious. Definitely will come here again
author: Jennifer R.

description: For small plates I think this place is a little overrated and quite expensiveI probably wouldn't come back
author: Rod M.

description: Chicken skewers was yummy I wish their chicken had more flavors but overall very nice and unique place with friendly staff. :)
author: Mahnoush T.

description:
I probably go here at least once a week either for their awesome lamb burger, unlimited mimosa brunch or just a glass of wine and some hummus. 

It's a cool, relaxed spot on Polk Street that has become one of my go-to spots when I'm hungry or even when I don't know what else to do! 

Quality of the food is consistent and the prices are reasonable. If there's something you don't like or are missing, just ask. The staff is very accommodating.
author: Billy G.

description: Great food with friendly service. The ambience is really nice. We tried the borek, salmon, adana kebab and kunefe. Everything was delicious.
author: Cihan U.

description: Great ambiance with great selection of wine. The Mediterranean food options are very good too. Great taste and plating of food, and pefect to pair with a nice glass of wine.
author: Lisa O.

description: Came at noon. I ordered kofte plate. It said it comes with rice and vegetables. It came with little rice and vegetables but not good taste at all. They seemed like been previously frozen. The meat came raw and we waited 15minutes plus we were the only customers in this facility (and now i know why). Food doesnt match the price in any possible way. Never coming here again.
author: Viko P.

description:
We came here for lunch because Mediterranean sounded good, and I was pleasantly surprised at how good it was.  There were no issues with getting seated, but getting the waiter's attention was a little tough.  It looked like there was only one waiter for the entire place, so he was busy.  

I really liked the decor in here, its cute and casual but a little dim inside.  We got a few kebabs, I liked the Kofte a lot, especially with a side of taziki.  Bonus points for our tea in mason jars.

I'd like to come back to check out HH.
author: Lyn C.

description: We came here for Sunday brunch to try Benedict eggs with Mediterranean twist. Usually to rate a place I look for 3 things: general ambiance of the place, food taste and service. The place is clean and cozy. The girl named Tumar, who served us was very attentive. We got the menu, and while we were looking on it she served the water and coffee. Refill was always on time. I went with the salmon Benedict eggs and they were delicious. There is a little room to improve this dish by putting less salt on salmon, but I guess it is subjective for everyone. Definitely recommend this place.
author: Darkhan B.

description: Prawns were excellent.   Tziki was rich and creamy.   Meatballs we're tasty.  Good red wine suggestion.  Nice easy vibe and service.  Definitely coming back here.
author: Brian N.

description:
Bah. Bah. That's my impression of a lamb.

Can't you tell where this is leading? To my review of their lamb burger of course.

Totally delicious and tender.

Their smoked salmon was equally fresh and good.

Dunya--like duh, why haven't I come here before?
author: Jack R.

description: Great food. They also recommended me a great sweet Riesling to pair. Calamari was awesome and the warm pita took the cake.
author: Shobhit S.

description:
I have to divide this review in 2 parts to be honest:
Food: it was 8 of us and everyone was happy with theirs food, we us musaka, appetizers, lamb burger and salmon. The food was really good and had a very Mediterranean flavor.
Friendliness: I don't know if we were simply not lucky but the waiter was super rude, he kept rushing us in trying to make us finish quick our dinner and take our plates away even when we were not done. He kept pushing us to take more wine even though we didn't want more and totally didn't deserve any tip even though we ended up giving him a lot!
author: Irina P.

description:
Went here during happy hour for a quick bite to eat and I can't say anything I got stood out as being particularly good.  I got a lamb burger that came with fries and a side salad.  The side salad had too much dressing, and the fries were cold/flavorless.  The burger itself had good flavor but way too much sauce and uninspiring toppings.  The menu said it would have feta but... I found no feta.

Aside from the blah food, service was friendly but inattentive.  I ran out of water and no one checked to see if my food was ok or if I needed more water even though the restaurant was practically empty and the servers were just hanging out by the bar.

Maybe the food & service are better during busier times?  I'd say this is decent place to grab something in a pinch but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat there again.
author: Robyn H.

description: Food is delicious and the wine selection is great. The staff are friendly and take a good care of the customers.
author: Niaz S.

description:
This place was really cute inside, I loved the decor and vibe. I went here for Saturday brunch and got bottomless mimosas - they were yummy (mostly champagne!) and a good price ($15), and they were refilled continuously! 

However, the food was incredibly overpriced and not filling - sad! I got the "Mediterranean ranchero". For $18 I got 1/4 cup of breakfast potatoes, 1/3 cup lightly dressed greens, a small round of pita spread with a small amount of hummus, a barely discernible amount of mozzarella, two poached eggs and a small amount of tomato sauce. Ingredients probably cost $2 in total (not even any meat), yet they charged $18. Craziness!! I could've eaten two easily.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
Absolutely amazing! Every single bite of everything was so flavorful and delicious! Couldn't get enough! Service superb too. Ambience, lights cute and lil romantic - cool for date maybe not do much for big group although they have bar are space too. 
I think what I'll remember about the most if how fresh every tasted! Yummmmm.... can't wait to go back!
author: Wioleta O.

description: Just had Calamari Palermo and three glasses of a fantastic Spanish sparkling rose!  Was at a tour at the antique vibrator museum across the street and stopped for a drink.  My sparkling was great and the calamari was fantastic!! Thank you!
author: Betsy C.

description: When i arrived Dunya, i was little nervous because please is very busy but they accommodate us in 15 min. So i had a prosciutto Benedict the meal is very delicious poach just perfect not runny nor over cooked and very creamy hollandaise !! My friend had prosciutto omelet, size of meal is huge and very delicious. I would highly recommended their weekend brunch.  Service is good and waiters friendly. Best part is bottomless mimosa for a good price. We love this place and definitely we ll come back . Well done Dunya .
author: Cem C.

description: We happened to be in the area around 5 pm on a Saturday evening and were looking for good drink/appetizer options when we spotted Dunya. It looked like a safe bet for my veggie friend and we pulled the bar stools and ordered a couple of drinks, falafel salad and truffle fries. We were simply blown away by the quality of both! The falafels, 4 in a plate, were perfectly fried to retain the taste, and topped with tahini sauce. Truffle fries were fried in fresh oil, topped with a good amount of parmesan cheese slices. Due to the happy hour (3-6 pm), my pilsners came to 4$ each and my friend's wines had 25% off. Our server was perfectly attentive to our needs. The ambience was also very warm and inviting. Would definitely revisit and recommend!
author: Sid W.

description:
We tried to go to "My My" for brunch but they were closing - so we went here.  The room is pretty - but even for me - SUPER LOUD (what?)

But the loud is not the problem, the food just has so much potential it was sad to see what they were doing.

For $12 I ordered the corned beef hash - as recommended by the waiter over the interesting sounding ground lamb and eggs.  The corned beef pieces were the only thing saving this place from 1 star. The corned beef was real and in big pieces, and tender (I am wondering if they get it from Miller'sEast Coast deli down the street.)  Yet the poached eggs on top were over done, there were green peppers in the hash (albeit big enough pieces to actually get rid of). The potatoes on the side did not have a hint of crispy on them. The water is served without ice (what is this disturbing trend lately?, we Americans love our ice - and this gal in particular loves her ice). 

I did try my gf's tatziki omelet and it was good...maybe this just isn't the place for brunch, maybe its better for Mediterranean food.  

To top it off, and this was not the restaurant's fault - but I was staring at some guys 2" of ass crack at the table across the way... not pretty ;(
author: Amy W.

description:
At first glance, Dunya looks a lot more like a Spanish tapas/wine bar than a Turkish place, but the servers are friendly and the food is fine. Nothing to call home about, but not a bad place for a glass of wine and some apps.

The mezze platter had a good mix of items, though portions feel like they should be slightly larger. Two dolma and two falafel balls aren't easy to split. The muhammara was the stand-out item here, smoky and nutty.

The lamb kebab was somewhat tough, but the seasoning was on point. The lavash bread underneath did a good job of soaking up a lot of the grilling sauces.
author: Kevin L.

description: We had a good meal here. The food was delicious (chicken skewers with rice & vegetables, and a few appetizers) with lots of flavor. The service was warm & friendly. Will definitely go back!
author: Ruth C.

description: The wine selection at this place is pretty terrible we tried two different Boudreaux with disgust. The cheese plate is extremely mediocre and when we asked for another strawberry we were told no without any explanation. The floor was slippery and three guest including myself almost slipped. This was brought to the attention of a male staff member whom did nothing about it. The best things we had was hummus. I would not visit this establishment again as there are far more superior wine bars close by.
author: Mercedes G.

description:
Perfect little neighborhood spot with great food. We came during happy hour and split the hummus, dolma, and soup.

Everything tastes great and the staff is very friendly. Ambiance is on point, feels very warm with dim lighting.
author: Jessica M.

description: Came here for a late lunch on a Friday and sat at one of the booth tables.  We ordered the mezze platter that comes with hummus, dolma, falafel , pita, baba ganoush, and something else.  We also got one of the meat dishes to share.  It came with two meat skewers, rice, and veggies.  Everything was very good.  I would definitely go back here.
author: Rachel R.

description: This is definitely a great little place near the hotel. The staff is wonderful and the ambiance is so comfortable. There is jazz/big band music playing and the kitchen is open concept so you constantly smell the wonderful creations coming from it. Will surely be back very soon. Oh and the food it out of this world!! I wish I had more stomachs!
author: Gena B.

description: Brunch was pretty good (bottomless mimosas as well). Friendly service. Overall a good time. Only complaint was that they manipulated our tip amounts - so keep your receipts and call them out for being shady!
author: J F.

description: In truth--the line for Swan's was a deal-breaker---for my STARVING teenager. Ducked out of line to get a latte at Moka-a few doors up the street and they recommended Dunyā. Never made it back to Swan's. Delicious lamb meatballs and borek, cozy and warm interior, great service. Not big, but a great neighborhood place that we don't have in Vegas. Sooo good!
author: CJ J.

description:
It's nice to have a bottomless brunch option where you know there won't be a crazy wait to be seated and for that, Dunya does a job for boozy weekend brunch. 

Some eyebrows raised around the mimosas though. Served in Brita-like pitchers, it's mysteriously clear which got us to think that it's probably a powdered orange mix they're using... kinda like Tang. However, the staff compensates by being very friendly and attentive, frequently doing the rounds to keep you topped up. I had the lamb burger at brunch that seemed to be a highlight and it was a pretty tasty burger. The lamb was well-seasoned and juicy. The fries looked good but disappointed. They could've been crispier and used more salt. The side salad - a generic afterthought. It's a tasty burger but competition at the $14 level is pretty tight and there are plenty of really good burgers at that price point that perhaps overshadow this one. 

Still, for a lazy brunch in the neighborhood, you shouldn't discount Dunya because the service here is really good and the food is decent enough without having to wait long to be seated.
author: Jon L.

description: Came here to just grab a glass of wine with my husband and ended up staying for a couple drinks and dinner. Such a delicious selection of food, loved the calamari, and the service was great too! We will definitely be returning!
author: Robyn M.

description:
I really can't complain about the food. Just one incidence of rude service, but that's all it takes to sour me on a place.

My wife and I stumbled into this place a month or so ago and had a wonderful time. Excellent food, charming and attentive service, really great lighting. We sat at one of the small corner tables that book-end the entrance. 

We are in this neighborhood frequently and when we saw it was open at 3 pm on a recent Saturday afternoon, we had no doubt where we enjoy an early meal.

That all changed immediately. Three of the six sidewalk tables were empty. Inside, five tables were free -- not to mention the completely empty long table adjacent to the bar. A four-top, two two-tops, plus both corner tables. (It's worth mentioning here that the corner tables are the same size as the two-tops but have the added charm of being in a corner, allowing for a more intimate dining experience.)

The waiter/host directed us to one of the two-tops. I politely asked if we could have one of the charming corner tables. He abruptly said those tables were for three people only. (I dare any three people to eat full-size plates at one of those tables.) 

I replied by pointing out that the restaurant had eight empty tables, not to mention the long table by the bar.

He grimaced and gestured again at the two-top. "That is what we have for you."

My wife and I looked at each other, spun on our heels, and left. Screw that crap. We took our appetites and our money down the street to Lemongrass (lemongrasssf.com) and had a wonderful meal.

We might be particular but the quality of the food and environment at any establishment are insufficient. The dining experience includes and even depends upon polite treatment. If a place is half-empty and it's not yet 3 pm, let the customer have their requested table.

There are more restaurants in SF than we can ever hope to experience in one lifetime. Why put up with rude treatment?
author: Andrew D.

description: This food was amazing!!! I loved this place! I had the lamb beef kabobs and I cleaned the plate. Delicious!
author: Jake B.

description: Very good Mediterranean food, prices are reasonable and good vibe in this little place. Parking can be challenging. Service is ok. Try the hummus
author: Raul P.

description:
Tonight we odered - 
Falafel salad - Absolutely Brilliant!! We shared this between 3 of us and were all fans. 
Lamb Skewers - Good 
Lamb Burger - Pretty plain
Vegan Stack - Pretty plain but tasty and healthy

They seat 3 at tiny tables with very little room. The food came out quick, but service was generally inattentive. 

Toilets are really modern and clean, despite being one toilet for everyone.
author: Candice C.

description:
Came here on Sunday for the bottomless mimosas and to try brunch with a Mediterranean twist. 

Our server, Ahmet, was awesome. He was friendly and knowledgable, and made sure our mimosas were kept full.

We started with a traditional hummus, eggplant and tzatiki platter, and borek- filo dough fried and filled with feta cheese and cooked to perfection. 

Ahmet recommended to try the Mediterranean ranchero, so my friend went with that. Pita bread baked with cheese, hummus, topped with pommodoro sauce and 2 eggs. I kept it simple with the Polk omelette- bacon and avocado. The boyfriend had French toast and smoked salmon omelette. All of our plates were clean by the end of it- we were satisfied to say the least.

We somehow saved room for baklava, it is made in house and is a must try! 

I would recommend making a reservation if you go on a weekend because it was starting to get pretty busy as we headed out around 12:30. 

Highly recommend!
author: Taylor M.

description: Went for brunch on Sunday - food is alright but service so slow that we had to wait almost half an hour to place an order. Plus two friends of mine who were doing bottomless brunch had to stand up and get the bottle to fill up their glasses as no one was pouring them more... overall, it was okay but wouldn't go back
author: Laurie H.

description: Dunya is one of my favorite brunch spots in the city. I recommend the Mediterranean Ranchero-- so delish and unique! But if that's not your thing, I've tried most items on the menu and you can't go wrong. On top of that, the atmosphere is pleasantly different and the wait is never absurdly long. They also offer $15 bottomless mimosas with brunch, if you're into that. Dunya is the (not-so-hidden) hidden gem of Polk Street! I'm planning on coming in for lunch and dinner soon.
author: Nicole W.

description: My friend and I were visiting San Francisco and stopped in this amazing little place for drinks and a quick bite. We were greeted by an inviting bar and friendly host. We ordered the Malbec and Mezze platter. Service and food was divine! When in San Fran, you must stop by and say Hi and eat at Dunya!
author: Heather O.

description:
This is my third, and probably last, time I'll try this place out again. There are too many nice restaurants on Polk street here to go waste spending my money here.

I see quite a few items on the menu that attract me. The mediterranean inspired  appetisers and entrée for brunch and lunch/dinner look good on paper but in reality I've mixed emotions about them. 

I like the wine list and the bar specials with midweek happy hour from  3-5pm Monday to Friday and weekend brunch specials with bottomless mimosas. 

Today when I stopped by Dunya, I said I was going to try their brunch. Wanted to change things up instead of going to my usual stomping grounds (MyMy, Toast or Dottie's True Blue Café)

Ambiance: Cozy, Mediterranean/Arabic décor, intimate

Hospitality: lack lustre, uninviting, lukewarm. 
Upon entering the restaurant, a group of the servers and the owner/manager were having a discussion and I just stood in the doorway waiting to be greeted and escorted to a table. It felt like I was not important and that my business wasn't needed.
My server didn't even introduce herself to me when I was seated. Didn't inquire if it was my first time or not. Didn't even make any appetiser/entrée  suggestions. I had to ask her what was her favourite items on the menu and her response was very "matter-of-factly". 
The only members of staff that had a pleasant demeanour and displayed a genuine sense of hospitality and appreciation for my business was the latin back-waiter/bartender and one of the latin line cooks that de-greeted me when I got up to leave. Because of these two individuals I gave this restaurant review two stars, otherwise it would've been just one. Probably I may come back because of them. Still deciding.

Food: 
Lamb Meat app: presentation, simple and beautiful. tomato sauce: bright and tangy, feta: salty deliciousness. Each meatball was stuffed with a black olive, unique, love it. The meatballs could've been cooked more thoroughly, it was a bit too rare for me. They were seasoned well though.
Ground Lamb Scramble: I was looking forward to his entrée but it was a major let down. I'm a self proclaimed foodie and I take pictures of most of my meals, except this one. For one, the potatoes were done well, good seasoning, portion was a bit. The scrambled eggs with ground lamb was really disappointing. The portion size was really small and barely enough seasoning. It wasn't attractive. We some work in the presentation department for this one. I asked for a side of avocados with my entrée and it looked like they literally scooped the avocado out of its skin and plopped it on my plate. 

I ate my brunch nonetheless, but I was reminiscing how I should've gone to my regular spots and spent the $35 elsewhere. Mmm, now I'm salivating over Dottie's Lamb Marquez sausage omelette, should've gone there instead, farther away, but worth the wait and trip.

Dunya's, I really want to like your place and food but I don't think I'm coming back.
author: hans simon f.

description: Food was good, but waiter Haniel is horrible! pizza was on the floor, all over the floor right next to my table, I told him, he just ignored it, we had to eat watching puzza on the floor
author: Saikal K.

description: Friendly staff, great food, good atmosphere.  They went out of their way to make my family comfortable on an otherwise hectic day.  Mezze platter was fresh, tasty, and plenty of food.
author: Christopher M.

description: Went with a date here. Not a worth the prices. Service is bare minimum. Both of our dishes tasted the same. Meh.
author: Savannah L.

description: This place became a routine for me cause the food is AWESOME!!! Stuff is very friendly and very nice wine selection. I highly recommend.
author: Sahap B.

description: Amazing service. Quality food. Great drinks. Came here for Turkish food and I was not disappointed! Got the Beyti and the Adana Kebab. Wish I had more room to get the Kunafa. Maybe next time.
author: Majid A.

description: I live right around the corner so I have been here multiple times. I would highly recommend their weekend brunch. It's bottomless for a good price, the waitstaff is helpful and friendly and the food is great!
author: Carol N.

description: We ate here for brunch. Place was not crowded for some reason. The food was fresh and good. Bottomless mimosa was outstanding. Staff were friendly and amazing. Will definitely go back.
author: Sig D.

description: We had the calamari and hummas and a couple malbecs. It was refreshing, light and full of flavor. Great place and I would definitely recommend it.
author: Sharon M.

description: I went to Dunya for lunch earlier today with a bunch of friends. It was an ok experience overall. The mezze platter appetizer taste better than I expected and the chicken shish kebab wrap was average at best. Service was pretty good and the server was friendly. I guess because we were the only group at that time right before happy hour starts. Atmosphere was nice but I still think that the price is pretty high for what you get. Would I come back? Probably yes but not anytime soon.
author: Mariner Z.

description:
Hands down awesome spot. Happy hour everyday is awesome. An amazing selection of wine and beers. Really nice staff who were also very knowledgeable. Their wine are particularly good.

They also have a great food, worth trying little bit of everything. Definitely one of my new staples to go to in SF!
author: John S.

description:
My review is more for the waitress than the food, which unfortunately I was never able to try. After being ignored when I walked in and eventually seating myself, I had to fetch the waitress to ask for water and a menu. She never came back to take an order, so again, I went and got her. After 30 mins in this place, she brings me the wrong order. "Oh, well do you want this?" She asks. Awful. 
Disappointed, as the food looked great, but I won't be back if she's there.
author: Sara P.

description:
Had high hopes but it was just OK.

Hummus was so-so (too lemony) but the pita was fresh and warm. For the size, the hummus appetizer was a bit overpriced. 

We ordered the lamb and prawn kebabs so we could try each. The lamb was tough and chewy- not tender/juicy. Prawn were the best bites of the night. 

The accompanying vegetables weren't that exciting but the grilled onions were tasty. Rice was decent.

Didn't try the wine but they have an extensive wine bar in the restaurant.

Service was fine. The seating is a little tight along the wall and it's hard to get in and out without disturbing those next to you.

I have to say that there are better Yemeni, Moroccan, Afghan, and Lebanese places in the area with better food that's cheaper. I probably won't be back to Dunya.
author: Semuteh F.

description: Great mediterranean spot in Nob Hill! Their food is well done and sold at a fair / good price point. The servers are so friendly, and you can drop in and usually get a table unless it's their super busy time. We frequent this restaurant 2x a week and are never disappointed!
author: Laura T.

description:
A-OK. Nothing went horribly wrong, but nothing went absolutely fantastic either. It didn't exceed my expectations in other words.

The food is decent, the price too high for the amount you get.
The interior is cozy but it get's too loud if you want to have a decent conversation.
The service is good.
author: Judith S.

description:
This place is a LOOT market! They are literally robbers! I have no better words to say.

They charge "tourists" 20% tip, as they say is their restaurant policy. How do they know you are a tourist? Well, they assume it and make random guesses. Worse yet, they say its 20% tip, but its more than that. Ours was 22%. And the server kept saying she has no idea why do have such a retarded policy since its what the manager decided and the manager was absent in the restaurant!

The food was decent but they are literally robbers. So if you are a tourist, and if you end up here, make sure you check your bill! We are SF residents, and we still paid 22% tip since they assumed that we were tourists. I'd say never go to such a place!!
author: Kinnary J.

description: Saw this place on yelp and decided to try it out with some friends. We got a bunch of plates and shared them. We were all really pleased with the food and the service was great.
author: Meagan D.

description: Came here for dinner last week and while I wasn't disappointed, there is nothing special about this place. Everything tasted just as I expected it would. Wasn't packed at peak hours so no need for a reservation. Meat kababs were a little dry.
author: Lucy C.

description: The Angus Burger (and the home made fries) is among the best I've eaten so far. Prices are not cheap but reasonable (for the quality and SF). Highly recommended.
author: Stefan H.

description:
Ok food but terrible service.  The place is visibly under staffed. One girl working bar and the floor at the same time. 
The place wasn't even half busy.  We waited forever for another drink and the glass of water never showed up.   

The name Dunya is also confusing.   Sounds like Russian but the menu is middle eastern to Mediterranean. 

 We won't go back there any time in the future.
author: Alex R.

description:
I have to say I don't understand the hype about this place. I went at a happy hour time to get food/dinner. The decor was nice, rustic, and kind of cool. They have a nice wine selection. 

The food was really only mediocre. We ordered a lentil soup that was just ok, tasted a bit better after adding lemon inside. Here's the weird part: We ordered a whole fish which was grilled very perfectly, meat tasted fresh. But it has this smelly, rotting smell that is similar to smelly cheese or stinky tofu. We asked the waitress (who was super duper nice to us, by the way) to ask the kitchen what they put in it. We expected the answer to be some kind of secret Turkish spice or fish paste, then we'll be ok with it. But the answer came back to be lemon. 

Our waitress was super nice though - she decided to waive the fish dish for us and it was on the house eventually. It's still a mystery to me what was put on that fish that was smelling so weird! We just knew it couldn't be just lemon!
author: Wendy K.

description:
Love the low key vibe and lack of a wait associated with Dunya's brunch!

I went to Dunya with a very large party for a bottomless mimosas brunch and we were all thoroughly pleased with the endless mimosas and all of the entrees. Although, none of the entrees stood out as particularly noteworthy (like the Challah French Toast at Olea or the Truffle Benedict at Mission Beach Cafe), the general quality across the board was up there. 

I had the smoked salmon benedict with house potatoes and was very satisfied. It was exactly what you'd expect out of a smoked salmon benedict - smoky, savory and creamy. The mimosas were a bit heavier on the Champagne than the OJ but hey, when has that ever been a bad thing? 

I highly recommend Dunya for brunch if you're looking to have a great bottomless time with several friends without the annoying SF brunch wait. 

Happy Eating, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description:
Came here for brunch on a Saturday afternoon and it was a pretty good experience, but nothing truly outstanding.

FOOD:
-Borek: This might have been the best thing on the menu. It's essentially a warm crispy eggroll filled with cheese and parsley.
- Mezze Platter: This was nice for sampling all the different mezes - we ordered 2 for a group of 8 and it was the perfect portion. Nothing exceptional on the platter though..
- Proscuitto Panini - This was slightly disappointing for me. It was just a really salty sandwich..and wasn't the right balance at all. Hardly tasted the mozzarella...meh.

Over, the food was alright, but nothing really exceptional. 

Pros:
I did like the overall ambiance of the place, it was pretty spacious and I liked how they could accommodate our group of 8.

They were super nice to our bday girl, and gifted her with a free drink and really good baklava.

Bottomless Mimosas also didn't hurt either...though they started to get more and more orangethe longer we stayed (as the champagne to juice portion started to diminish) haha, oh wells.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Dunya is a quiet and quaint little joint. 

Food: My sister and I split the ararat salad + chicken shish kebab. The ararat salad was so good! Such a perfect balance of flavors and it really is such a light and delicious salad. The chicken was also good-we split the veggies, the rice, the flat bread, and the skewers. All really good flavors. 

Service: They offered wine tasting of the daily special wine and didn't even card us (Mind you, I turned 19 in November.. so should I be offended or flattered that they think I'm that old?). My sister really liked it and it was the perfect pour right before the Asian glow begins.. haha! They kept refilling our water which was good. But something super annoying was that somebody came to take our plates when we still had some left on it.. 30 seconds later, another person.. 20 seconds later, another person.. 10 seconds later, another person before we snapped and just ate the remaining tomatoes and cucumbers. That's annoying to people sitting at the bar trying to have a personal conversation and savoring our salad! 

Atmosphere: super cozy and cute. Very hip SF style. 

It's a bit pricey but I think you pay more to enjoy the company you have in a cute restaurant.
author: Shelley K.

description:
The staff is super untrained and unable to do their job. One of them was so clumsy he wasn't able to keep 2 glasses of iced coffee on his tray and poured everything on me and my boyfriend. He barely apologized and went back to work. We of course had to leave the restaurant and our friends immediately since we were covered in iced coffee. Too bad because the owner was nice, but I'll never go back there. Being a waiter requires skills and training! If you're not able to take an order and carry heavy glasses on a tray, go do something else.

UPDATE: I had a comment that it was an accident. Indeed it was, but the restaurant should have offered something to fix the situation and make us want to come back. The waiter just left and we didn't get any free meal or an invitation to come back for a free diner or even a free coffee. Also, I just described a single event among a bunch of things that happened beforehand. Hence this review.
author: Doriane M.

description:
A Sunday morning at 11am: I couldn't decide if I wanted to go out for lunch to try kebabs, or brunch to have french toast.  Well would you know, this place has both!  Oh, and bottomless mimosas too!  

Kofte kebab was ok.  I wouldn't call it authentic Mediterranean and I've definitely had better. But the hot sauce saved it (the hot sauce here is awesome). 

The french toast was pretty good.  No fancy toppings, just straight up good french toast with syrup.  

Finally, the bottomless mimosas rock and are the reason for giving this place four stars.  They aren't watered down and are quite tasty. Moreover, the servers were on top of keeping the refills coming. Great service!
author: Riz W.

description: Bottomless mimosas was a definite win. But if you are in the area this is the place to go. Got a prosciutto Benedict and it was great. Pushing 2 hours and I'm still on my mimosas. This place is great.
author: Mike S.

description:
OMG, Sundays, it's $12 bottomless mimosas, and it's a damn good one, great food, friendly staff.  I sat at the bar and Carlos was the server, he's a nice guy, funny, and a true professional. 

I really wish I had discovered this place sooner.  I've been wasting my life at Toast and Mel's and neighborhood cafés.  This place is spankin!

It's only been open for 2 years so a lot of people may not know about it (I didn't anyways!) but it's a must try!
author: Brandon E.

description: I went with my boyfriend and felt instantly like family.  They treat you so well, very welcoming, and try to make sure even a normal dinner was special.  I don't eat meat but had plenty of options and went with the salmon, it was perfectly cooked and great flavors. My boyfriend had the Adana kebab and raved that it was as good as some of the ones he had in Germany (a big Turkish population).  You can't go wrong here, great date night for us.
author: Vittoria Z.

description: Small little restaurant and beautifully decorated. The food was delicious and they have bottomless mimosas  Would definitely come back!
author: Arlett F.

description: It was our first time in Dunya and it definitely won't be our last! We shared a meze plate first as an appetizer, which was a  delight. For the main course we had musakka and beyti and they didn't disappoint either. All the sauces and various flavors complimented each other very nicely. Kunefe was amazing! Finally the staff is very friendly and ambiance very romantic.
author: Çağlar A.

description: When is the stupid trend of serving good beer in a jar going to end? It ended long ago in most places in Europe when beer drinkers got tired of looking at the vine drinkers not having their vine served in a glass jar. It's stupid and not showing good beer any respect.
author: Frank S.

description: My first meal in SF Amazing appetizer babaganouj (eggplant pureé) was awesome and the shrimp skewer entrée was as delicious as the appetizer. The salmon carppacio my date ordered for her appetizer looked great i don't remember what her entrée was but I'm sure it was great. No desert that night. All in all a great first meal on my first visit to San Francisco
author: Marc G.

description:
Was excited to try this place. I came here with a small group of co-workers during lunch time.
The service was perfect. Our server was attentive, quick and very polite.
The food, however, was not really what I expected based on the reviews. (Maybe it was because we came during lunch?)

For the table, we had the tzatziki, which I really enjoyed. Light and creamy!
I ordered the smoked salmon panini. The combination of the fish and the goat cheese made it quite salty! The others at my table ordered the angus burger (heard it wasn't anything special), chicken pesto panini and the ararat salad, which looked quite refreshing!

I'm hoping I'll be able to make it back. The place is quite cute!
author: Mimie L.

description: Really, really bad. They got both orders wrong and somehow forgot to add anything but tomatoe juice to the bloody mary. I get the vibe this place is a front.
author: Jameson S.

description: Good variety on the happy hour menu @ decent prices. Portions are good sizes, for two. The hummus was great and the calamari is served in a sweet tomato sauce that is really tasty. Most people come for the bottomless mimosas I think
author: Jared N.

description: Best baklava ever..it is a great selection of wine and delicious food! Glad we have casual classy Dunya in Polk
author: Dennis Uluç' T.

description: Ahmet is the best server I have ever had. He fills up your mimosa before you even know you need it filled. The food is amazing too. I highly recommend this restaurant for brunch. Ask for Ahmet to serve you!
author: Izzie O.

description: One of the best restautants in US in its price range. Some Turkish foods such as mezes, lamb skewers and kunefe are even better than most of the restaurants in Turkey. I spent 5 days in SF and ate in Dunya 3 times. It was addictive and worths your money. The only bad thing is their prices differ around 2$ in their website which is negligiable if you want to eat something "wonderful".
author: Mesut Ü.

description:
If you happen to walk by and you're in the mood for turkish/mediterranean, give it a try. But as you're perusing the menu,e my falafel salad was SO overdressed with vinaigrette, it was basically a pile of saturated green leaves with falafel balls topped with sauce and another dollop of wet guacamole ontop of THAT. I mean, another pound of lettuce greens might have made it balance out ok.
Otherwise, place was cute and I'd go back =)
author: Christine Y.

description: Fabulous shish kebab chicken and lamb and the waiter Yuksel was outstanding you should ask for him.
author: Michael M.

description: I've been meaning to put this review up for a while. We came here last month for brunch with friends. The Mediterranean inspired food is interesting, and the menu contains some flavorful combinations. The food quality was a little meh (wilting greens), but what really got me was the eye roll I got from the server when I asked for my omelette with egg-whites and dressing on the side. Sorry dude, I know you're a hipster with no patience for my yuppie ways, but your restaurant is NOT fine dining and this is California. Get used to it. Since the fact that I'm trying to eat healthy makes you really annoyed, I will go elsewhere.
author: Jill O.

description:
This place was a true 'find' and a great, cozy, comfort-food sort of dinner that I very much needed after a stressful day.

The manager tucked us in the front of the restau near a window, at a table reserved for people coming in another couple hours.  

The place is dark with red lighting, and that in and of itself was lovely.

I ordered the red lentil soup, which to me was really just ok - too heavy on the tomato sauce which overtook the pure goodness of the lentil. Oh well.

We three also ordered the lamb meatball appetizer, which were stuffed with spices, olives, feta, etc - and were downright delicious, and big!  Thankfully there was one for each of us!

I ordered, for my main, the mezes platter - which came with Falafel - which I'd never tried before and, as I am not a HUGE fan of fried food - to me was 'just OK', muhammara - something also new to me, apparently made from dried red peppers and walnuts, which was interesting and lovely, hummus - great, of course, dolma - good but not as good as my father-in-laws;), eggplant salad - not my fave but not bad, and tzatziki - my all-time fave for sure!

I can't speak to what my brother in law got b/c I didn't have a chance to try it. My husband got the salmon and it was cooked impressively well in the "provencal" style, which of course is clearly a French influence.

The wine here was very good as well. I would definitely go back if I lived nearby. 
I would also normally give this 3.5 stars, but considering it saved a portion of my day, it gets moved up to 4.  ^-^
author: Valerie J.

description: The service was great and the food was delicious. I also like the ambiance of the place. It's not brightly lit and it's not too loud
author: Arun Kumar C.

description: GREAT place to eat! Very good food, excellent, personable customer service. The waiter joked around with us without making it uncomfortable, and they were very attentive. I left my sunglasses there by mistake, they held on to them, and they even recognized me when I came back, waving me over as soon as I entered. Great place!
author: Michael F.

description: Excellent food, good wine, prices are right and the owner and staff are warm hearted. Definitely worth repeated visits.
author: Mike H.

description: Everything was delicious and fresh. Great service and location.  Thank you for a marvelous taste of San Francisco we will be back. ..
author: Mori D.

description:
Nice place . Nice foods .
Waitress was really good.
Clean ! 

Kunefe looks goods , mixed kebab us delicious ! 

But ...
Turkish restaurant is good with turkish tea or coffee ... 
After having lunch I really wanted to drink a cup of tea , but waitress told me that they dont have turkish one and they can offer only teabags . 

For me turkish coffee and tea are something amazing , especially after heavy meal like kebab. 

That's why , I really want that in the future drink a cup of tea there after having a good dinner .
author: Jay M.

description: Usually love this place for brunch but last time our mimosas tasted terrible. How do you mess up a mimosa? I don't even know. I told the server we didn't like them and he was incredibly rude. He still charged us even after we voiced our concerns.
author: Beau D.

description:
Parking is horrible but the food makes up for it. Note to self ... if you live in the city do not attempt to find parking around polk. 

Must have the eggplant puree. For all the desi people reading my review this is Baingan Bharta served cold with pita and kicks ass of any baingan bharta I've had in the city. Follow this up with Lentil soup which is tangy perfection. OMG I totally love it. Will be coming back for some MOAR Lentil soup soon !
author: Priyanka P.

description: The mixed grill platter was huge enough for two people! We left feeling ABSOLUTELY stuffed. The lamb skewers were my favorite! So flavorful. And chicken wasn't dry at all! When it comes to Mediterranean chicken I'm always afraid the chicken will be too dry. NOT HERE! Service is attentive and prompt, and they have a great wine selection. Ask for hot sauce!
author: Alexis P.

description:
My go to Mediterranean place.  

They have an amazing lamb burger - definitely my favorite on the menu.  Their kebabs are very good too, as is the mixed platter starter.  Wine and beer only but good selection.  I do miss the full bar though :) 

Good sized portions and good service.  Generally not super full during the week but you'll have to wait for a bit on a Friday/Saturday.
author: Farid V.

description:
I was standing in the doorway with multiple servers making eye contact with me for 10 minutes. Finally someone acknowledged me and told me that the wait for a table was 5-10 minutes. I sat at a table outside for 45 mins! When I saw a group of people walk in and sit at the table they had just cleared off that I was patiently waiting for, I had enough! I walked back in the door and the waiter said that they just thought that I was waiting for a person that never came. I told them that I was a party of one! The waiter didn't apologize as much as he should've. All I could think of was that this food better be worth all of this! 

I give the lamb burger a 7/10. It was good but it could be better. I've had Künefe a number of times and the one I had for dessert did not fail my tastes buds, thankfully. I'd give the Künefe a 9/10. Although service was lacking the food was exceptional.
author: Genny H.

description:
I wasn't really looking for a new place to try around my girlfriend's neighborhood, but since she had a gift certificate to Dunya, the decision came easy for us. 

I knew I'd be circling around for parking, but five times around the half mile perimeter was a bit ridiculous. This being 8pm on a Saturday night, I should've expected it.  Cough up the $10 and park at the Jug Wine shop lot on Polk & Pacific sts. 

I wasn't feeling like my bubbly self so I needed a glass of bubby. It's well chilled and crisp, but I do have to comment on the stemware, please invest in a good flute. It downgrades the experience a bit considering this is a wine bar.  

We tried their Mediterranean sampler plate. The falafels were cooked a bit too crispy but came with a nice spicy sauce. The hummus was creamy and well balanced while I found the dolmas sub par -- the grape leaves itself being tougher than what I'm used to. 

Service was pleasant and they let us linger at the table even if they got a little busy later on. When our bill came, we used our restaurant.com certificate which the owner (gently) refused stating that he's been having issues with restaurant.com offering it on their website when they've told them not to. In exchange for our trouble, he gave us a $15 gift card for our next visit. Such gesture is considerate enough coming from the owner, but Dunya still has a lot of work to do. For now, I think 3 stars are fair enough.
author: Janice C.

description: Amazing food and excellent service. Be sure to try the Kurdish meatballs, and I love the small plates. Great warm and inviting atmosphere. Will be back.
author: J W.

description: Went last nite for dinner. It was amazing. Such tasty food it was so flavorful and traditional. Loved the Mezza plater and the lamb for main course also the best desserts I've ever tried. Very warm and sexy place. Will come back and back. Loved it.
author: Bella K.

description: Really great service. Reasonable prices. Bottomless mimosas on the weekends for 12$ until 3pm. Had the Chicken Kebab wrap, was really filling and delicious. The fries were also really good. I would definitely reccomend.
author: Madie H.

description:
I am a local, so I have been here a few times over the years. In the past I enjoyed the lamb burger. On a Sunday, after running a race, my boyfriend and I were looking for a place to eat. Lots of places had lines, and we laughed at people waiting, saying to ourselves, why would people wait? There are great spots everywhere. (Side note: I think Yelp has caused the lines! People now want to wait for awesome experiences v. going for a mediocre one!)

So we sat down really excited about the food to come. I ordered a Bloody Mary, they are a wine/ beer bar, so they offered me a mimosa instead. 

I ordered coffee, and promptly received a cup. There wasn't any cream or milk on the table, so I drank the first cup black. When the waiter returned to fill up my coffee, I asked for some milk. He brought cream, I just used that. 

To order, I thought both the pancakes and the French toast looked good. They were both 10 dollars, so I asked if I could have a smaller order of both. He said absolutely. When the bill came, he had charged me $17.00 for the order. Even though one of the orders came with fresh fruit, and it was an upsell on the other, they charged $3.00 for the fruit. 4 banana slices, two strawberries, 9 blueberries. (fruit was great!) 

When the order arrived, the pancakes and the french toast were luke warm and the syrup was almost cold. No butter was provided. They syrup wasn't maple and was an imitation cheapie something. When I asked if they could warm up the syrup they looked at me like I was crazy, and said "we don't do that". They ultimately did go to warm up the syrup, but they took the one from the table, and they took 10 minutes to come back. I had pretty much finished the entire meal by the time they returned, and ate more just so I could at least try the hot syrup. (Thank you for getting that, it really was necessary to warm up the food, and to enhance the flavor. I appreciated the time to do it.) 

Coffee was finished, wasn't offered a refill. 

My boyfriend ordered an omelette and toast and jam. The toast was not included (an additional $3, for an $11 omelette, typically in the city, toast is included. When he ordered the toast he asked for jam, the waiter first said they didn't really do jam but then said they did have a fig jam.  When the toast came out and we asked for jam from another waiter he responded with "We don't have jam". He did ultimately get some jam. The toast was only toasted on one side and completely not toasted on the other side. His omelette and potatoes were fine. Nothing to note one way or the other. 

I can't imagine going back here. For two people, without any booze, the bill was over $40 and the service and food was 2 stars. 

My advice would be to think through some of the small additions that could make a huge difference, whipped butter, a better toaster, cream on the tables, better pricing  and one good jam of the normal variety (strawberry is always safe), and better quality toast. 

I think the lamb burger is a safe bet, I would stick with that, or wait 20 minutes for another place. Sorry Dunya, I am Dun!
author: Danielle V.

description: Excellent food.  I ordered the falafel APPETIZER...  That thing was like an entree and then some! Super crunchy and delish.  We ordered some recommended red wine and were definitely pleased with how good it was.  We are making this our go-to spot on Polk!
author: Fawn M.

description: I've been to Dunya multiple times and the food has been great on every visit. The staff has always been attentive and helpful. They've made some great wine recommendations as well. Make sure to get some tzatziki!
author: Kate S.

description:
Ahmet, what a great server. Bottomless mimosas are on point, and Ahmet didn't give us a time limit. Bottomless until 3 means you drink until 3, no questions asked.

Also, the servings of sides... amazing. Usually you ask for a side of bacon for $3, and you get two slices. With Dunya, $2 gets you 6 slices of bacon. Well done, well done.

We'll be back Ahmet, looking forward to it my friend.
author: Devon G.

description:
Teamwork.

Good: Eggs and tomato sauce. Pita and hummus. Warm weather and San Francisco.

Exceptional: Mediterranean Ranchero with all the above all at once. Made even better thanks to outdoor seating on such a beautiful day.

Reasonable $13 cost especially considering the price includes a small side of potatoes. Staff was friendly and attentive. Food served impressively quick.

Amazing things happen when everyone works together.
author: Jason B.

description:
Great friendly service! 
Food is delicious, atmosphere is great , really nice place to have a dinner or drink! Next time I'm in SF I'll def stop in again! 
Yummy! Went back to the hotel full & happy!
author: Jill S.

description: A pleasant surprise. We were here for Sunday brunch but ordered from the lunch menu. The meze platter is perfect to share, and oh so very good. Yum yum yum. The hubs ordered the Musakka which was delicious. I had the Lamb shish kebab wrap which was good. We wanted to eat there again the following weekend but it was super packed for brunch. We'll try again.
author: Vol T.

description: Food was subpar. We got the lamb wrap, chicken salad, mujarah dip, and stuffed falafel. Not very tasty. The potato soup was good. We ordered a chicken dish which took over 40 minutes to come out. They told us the oven baked chicken takes longer but 40 minutes is ridiculous and they should really give people a heads up. We were finished with our meal by the time the dish came out. The staff were accommodating but kept explaining how the dish takes longer and it is on the way. Our waiter seemed annoyed by us liked we were being unreasonable for being displeased and impatient.
author: Jacqui C.

description:
Delicious Turkish food, prepared well and authentically, served up with great service. 
Everything we ate, from the appetizers to the lamb kabobs were so tasty....perfect seasoning and temperature. 
Small neighborhood gem. 
Don't pass this place up.
author: Nilu r.

description: I live for lamb. Not everyone prepares it well. I assume Mediterranean spots would be great at preparing lamb, but I've been failed by this assumption. Not this time. Dunyan is super cute, quaint, and lux. The lamb was better than I hoped for. The spice on the skewers superb. The burger juicy with a great bun. Only critic would be the truffle fries were less desirable. Overall great place will definitely be back.
author: Well B.

description:
I ordered the beyti for brunch; my boyfriend had the chicken shawarma. Reminds me of Troya in the Inner Richmond.

We had a great brunch here - the service was prompt, the food arrived quickly. With so many other brunch places full of people, this is an amazing alternative - instead of waiting 90 minutes at a nearby corner brunch place, we waited ... Zero minutes.

The portion sizes were decent and fresh. My beyti - with lamb, tomato sauce and creamy dipping - was to die for.

Great place to keep in mind for brunch!
author: Jen B.

description: The service was terrible. I went with a group of friends for lunch and our waitress was unfriendly. She seemed as if she didn't know what she was doing, never even introduced herself to us. Maybe she was new because she didn't know the menu and kept asking us where everything was. The food was good but I won't be going back because of the service.
author: Jenna P.

description: The bomb. Food is always fresh and amazing flavors. Obviously owned and operated because the service is impeccable.
author: Geno B.

description:
Surprisingly good. We had the combo plate- good and a lamb burger- perfect spice

I didn't have high expectations, but after my 1st experience I would come back
author: Leah B.

description:
Prices have gone way up (even by SF standards!) and the quality / portion sizes do no justify the expense. You can do better in the neighborhood. 

Also, the online menu doesn't reflect the latest pricing. Get it together!
author: Aseem G.

description:
Turkish food is so DIVINE and Dunya successfully delivered on flavorful food & an enjoyable experience overall.

The mezze platter is a must as you get a taste of a variety of the appetizers and then can decide what you like best:   platter consists of falafels, dolmas, muhammara, eggplant puree, hummus, and tzatziki - and tonz of pita bread!  The dolma and the muhammara were finger-licking good so we ordered seconds of those.  Calamari Palermo - sautéed with artichoke, kalamata olives, garlic, basil, red sauce was decent, the sauce was awesome for dipping with the pita.  The Ararat salad was light and refreshing.  Lamb shish kebabs were exquisite - 2 skewers of perfectly done lamb cubes (i hate chewy lamb) served with aromatic rice and veggies! All this yummy food was accompanied by two bottles of a cab-zin blend recommended by our waitress.  

We ended the night with 3 desserts, the baklava, the chocolate dome, and the mango pana cotta.  All 3 desserts were great and even though I'm a sucker for anything chocolate,  I have to say the mango pana cotta was just mind blowing and all of us pounced on it.....!

Highly recommend Dunya for a cozy dinner with a small group of friends or for a fun date night!
author: Bhavnak K.

description:
We were looking for a new place to try in a different neighborhood and we love mediterranean food so we wanted to give this a try. It was great. The environment is just right so that you can just enjoy the food and conversation. The food was amazing - we got the Rosemary Orange Olives and a couple other things to start and the Mixed Grill for entree to share between the two of us (with some extra rice). Very moist grilled meat and lovely rice. We'll definitely be back to explore the rest of their awesome menu. We ended with the Mango Panna Cotta - really nice for an option that's subtly sweet!

Prices are standard and the wine was nice! 

Other reviews comment on the service so I'll add to that as well: They are sweet but maybe seem a little confused at times. A bit more thorough knowledge of the menu would be good, but they were certainly accommodating and attentive albeit not obnoxiously so. We couldn't complain.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Great Mediterranean meal.  

The mezze plate and calamari together with the mixed grill and a vegan pyramid which was ample for 4 people.
